day1_quiz.title: Debt Payoff Strategies Quiz

questions.question: What's the key difference between the Avalanche and Snowball methods?
options: Avalanche focuses on highest interest rates, Snowball on smallest balances
Avalanche is for rich people, Snowball is for everyone else
Avalanche pays all debts equally, Snowball picks randomly
There's no real difference between them
questions.explanation: Avalanche prioritizes high-interest debt to save money, while Snowball targets small balances for psychological wins.

questions.question: You have: Credit Card ($2,000 at 18% APR), Student Loan ($8,000 at 4% APR), Personal Loan ($1,000 at 12% APR). Using the Snowball method, which debt would you tackle first?
questions.explanation: Snowball method focuses on the smallest balance first for quick psychological wins, regardless of interest rate.

questions.question: The Avalanche method will always save you more money in interest than the Snowball method.
questions.explanation: Mathematically, paying off highest interest debt first (Avalanche) will always result in less total interest paid.

day1_quiz.completion_message: Great job! You now understand the two most effective debt payoff strategies. Remember: the best method is the one you'll stick with!

day2_quiz.title: Categorize Your Spending
day2_quiz.description: Practice categorizing transactions to build spending awareness. This skill helps you see where your money actually goes!

questions.question: Drag each transaction to its correct category:
Which category do you think most people underestimate their spending in?
questions.explanation: Studies show people typically underestimate food & dining expenses by 40-60%. Those small purchases add up quickly!

questions.question: Why is categorizing transactions important for debt payoff?
options: It makes you feel guilty about spending
It helps identify where you can cut back to find extra money for debt payments
Banks require it for loan applications
It's only useful for tax purposes
questions.explanation: Categorizing reveals spending patterns and helps you find 'hidden' money you can redirect toward debt payments.

day3_quiz.title: Identify Your Debt Killers

questions.question: If you spend $4 on coffee every workday (5 days/week), how much do you spend on coffee per year?
questions.explanation: $4 × 5 days × 52 weeks = $1,040 per year. That's a significant amount that could go toward debt!

questions.question: Which of these 'debt killers' do you think impacts your budget most?
options: Premium options when basic would work
questions.note: There's no wrong answer - this is about self-awareness!

questions.question: What's ONE debt killer expense you're willing to reduce this week?
questions.prompt: Be specific: What will you change and how?
questions.example: I'll make coffee at home 4 days this week instead of buying it, saving about $16

day3_quiz.completion_message: Awareness is the first step! Small changes in spending create big changes in debt payoff speed.

questions.question: Match each financial term with its correct definition:
definitions: The original amount of money borrowed
Annual percentage rate - yearly cost of borrowing
Smallest payment required to keep account in good standing
Percentage of available credit you're using

correct_matches.APR: Annual percentage rate - yearly cost of borrowing
correct_matches.Principal: The original amount of money borrowed
correct_matches.Minimum Payment: Smallest payment required to keep account in good standing
correct_matches.Credit Utilization: Percentage of available credit you're using

questions.question: If you have a $5,000 balance on a credit card with 18% APR and only make minimum payments, approximately how much interest will you pay in the first year?
questions.explanation: $5,000 × 0.18 = $900. However, this assumes you don't pay down any principal. In reality, minimum payments reduce this amount slightly.

questions.question: You have two credit cards: Card A (22% APR, $3,000 balance) and Card B (15% APR, $4,000 balance). Using the Avalanche method, which should you pay off first?
options: Card A - higher APR costs more
questions.explanation: Avalanche method targets highest APR first. Card A at 22% is costing you more per dollar than Card B at 15%.

day7_quiz.title: Set Your Payment Commitment
day7_quiz.description: Commitment is what transforms a dream into reality. Let's set your debt payment goal and make it official!

questions.question: What's your current monthly debt payment total?
questions.helper_text: Add up all minimum payments across all debts

questions.question: Based on this week's learning, how much EXTRA could you realistically add to your monthly debt payments?
questions.helper_text: Think about the expenses you identified that you could cut

questions.question: Which debt payoff strategy will you use?

options.name: Avalanche
options.description: Pay minimums on all debts, attack highest APR first

options.name: Snowball
options.description: Pay minimums on all debts, attack smallest balance first

options.name: Hybrid
options.description: Start with one small debt, then switch to highest APR

day7_quiz.completion_message: 🎉 Congratulations! You've completed your first week of debt mastery. You now have the knowledge, strategy, and commitment to achieve financial freedom!
